snippet: President Obama pressed China on Monday to improve its record on human rights, while declining to discuss Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer who escaped house arrest.
abstract: Pres Obama gently prods China to improve its record on human rights, while declining to discuss Chen Guangcheng, blind lawyer who escaped house arrest; administration officials believe silence on the matter is their best chance to resolve the case, given the embarrassment Chen's escape has already caused Chinese leaders, who bristle at anything they perceive as foreign interference; both sides appear eager to avoid a standoff that could mar relations and, most immediately, eclipse upcoming annual talks.

byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ANDREW JACOBS
byline.contributor: Steven Lee Myers reported from Washington, and Andrew Jacobs from Beijing. Jane Perlez, Didi Kirsten Tatlow and Clare Pennington contributed reporting from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: President Obama pressed China on Monday to improve its record on human rights, while declining to discuss Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer who escaped house arrest.

headline.seo: Without Mentioning Chen, Obama Nudges China on Human Rights
headline.main: On a Tightrope, President Prods China on Rights
headline.print_headline: On A Tightrope, President Prods China On Rights

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject
